Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Inaugural Optics and Photonics Winter School and Workshop, College of Optical Sciences, Tucson AZ, January 5-20, 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Optics and Photonics Winter School and Workshop at the College of Optical Sciences January 5-10, 2016

Optics & photonics are important areas in which there is a growing national need for work-force development. A challenge is that many undergraduate schools are focused on traditional science and engineering curricula, to the extent that their students may not be fully aware of the opportunities for pursuing a career in optics & photonics. This grant will provide partial support for an inaugural Optics and Photonics Winter School and Workshop to be held at the College of Optical Sciences in Tucson, AZ from January 5-10, 2016. The winter school and workshop will be aimed at promoting, supporting, and strengthening optics & photonics education and research in the United States by engaging students and faculty at the undergraduate level. The inaugural Optics and Photonics Winter School and Workshop will be publically advertised. Participation will be by invitation only, but application is open to all interested parties. We plan to actively recruit approximately 10 faculty and 20 student participants for whom we can reimburse airfare, meals and lodging. Undergraduate participants will be recruited in part through nominations from invited faculty, but all undergraduate applicants will be considered for invitation and financial support, subject to the availability of funds. To cover these expenses we request partial support from the NSF in the amount of $15k. The expected impact of Optics and Photonics Winter School and Workshop falls in several areas. First and foremost, the event will promote and enhance optics and photonics education at the undergraduate level, thus encouraging more students to pursue a career in this area and making transparent the advantages of a graduate level education in an optics program. Secondly, the workshop provides PUI faculty and students with the opportunity to network with colleagues at similar undergraduate institutes, and with attendees from larger graduate schools and from the photonics industry. For faculty from primarily undergraduate institutes in particular, the cross-fertilization of optics pedagogy and approaches to successful research projects in the undergraduate environment will be extremely useful, especially for those who have fewer opportunities to network with the broader optical sciences community. As a result, PUI faculty and students will become more effective ambassadors for the field of optics in general, and better positioned to encourage the pursuit of graduate level optics & photonics education. This ultimately results in a stronger and more highly skilled workforce in optics and photonics to address the technological and scientific needs of our society.

The goal of hosting the Optics and Photonics Winter School will be to give undergraduate students an overview of key and foundational areas of optics and photonics, and how they are intimately related to specific fields of research, in hopes of encouraging more undergraduate students to pursue a career in those fields. The workshop is aimed at faculty members from primarily undergraduate institutes as well as undergraduates attending the Winter School. The workshop will provide a forum for undergraduate students and faculty members to share and/or learn of research and educational activities in optical sciences taking place at undergraduate institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Optics and Photonics Winter School and Workshop was held January 5-10, 2016, at the College of Optical Sciences in Tucson, AZ. The Optics and Photonics Winter School ran Jan. 5-7, and was aimed at promoting, supporting, and strengthening optics & photonics research in the United States by engaging students at the undergraduate level. The Optics and Photonics Workshop ran Jan. 8-10, and was aimed at faculty from primarily undergraduate institutes (PUI’s) as well as undergraduates attending the Winter School, providing a forum to share and/or learn of research and educational activities in optical sciences at undergraduate institutions.

The goal of hosting the Optics and Photonics Winter School was to give undergraduate students an overview of key and foundational areas, and how they are intimately related (and critical) to specific fields of optics & photonics research, in hopes of encouraging more undergraduate students to pursue a career in those fields. The goal of the Optics and Photonics Workshop was to provide a forum for PUI faculty and students to share results, approaches, and methodologies in optics & photonics research and education that are unique to the undergraduate setting, while at the same time exposing everyone to cutting-edge research and the exciting opportunities that await students beyond the undergraduate level.  

A website was created to provide detailed information on the events (see below). The meeting program and schedules are posted. In addition, all slides from the Winter School lectures are posted. Videos of all talks at the Winter School and Workshop are also available online at the website. Photos from the event are also available.

Website address:  http://wp.optics.arizona.edu/winter-school-workshop/

There were approximately 30 undergraduate students at the Jan 5-7 Optics and Photonics Winter School, and afterwards those same undergrads plus 14 faculty from their home departments attended the Jan. 8-9 Optics and Photonics Workshop.  Most attendees were from Predominantly Undergraduate Institutions (PUIs). Based on feedback from students and visiting faculty the overall event was extremely well received.  Many of the students expressed strong interest in applying for graduate programs in optics.   A few examples of comments and feedback include:

"I really felt that this school gave us access to experts in the field of optics. I was appreciative of their willingness to share with us.... The instructors were so willing to answer questions and make connections with us, even making their contact info available to us. They were very generous with their time and knowledge."  (student)

“Thank you again for inviting me to the Winter Workshop.  As a PUI faculty member in a physics department that has never sent any students (that I know of) to a graduate program in Optics, it was very helpful for me to learn about all the opportunities that students have when taking that career path.  The interaction with colleagues from both the University of Arizona and the other schools represented at the Workshop was highly valuable, as I was able to learn how they cover Optics topics in their curricula differently than at my institution.  The student from UWRF who attended the Winter School has told me that she wishes she could see all graduate programs in the same depth as her experience last week - she learned a great deal about optics and the wide range of research being done in that field.  I think she is more likely to choose that path than before she attended the Winter School.
